It's pretty standard practice these days to mix in a bit of %hp damage with most fighter champs. This helps them to have a slightly more similar TTK on tanks, fighters, and other squishies. If we gave them all flat damage, they would often end up just blowing up squishies at unreasonable speeds (see rengar).
But does it have to be so high? Like seriously his ult can easily do 45% and his W and 20%, for such a low cd it surely doesn't have to be such a high amount.
They scale very heavily on bonus AD to avoid the "build tank and do crazy damage" problem (see fizz, ekko). If he was not building damage, it would be much less.

>They scale very heavily on bonus AD to avoid the "build tank and do crazy damage" problem (see fizz, ekko).

No, that's not going to work, and after seeing how often %health damage has worked for tanks in the past, you guys should know this. His W provides him all the damage he needs even with building 0 AD beyond possibly Black Cleaver. He's going to do MORE damage over a long fight if he just builds pure tank and max cd and focuses on getting as many W procs out during a team fight as possible rather than building pure damage and blowing up after getting only one proc out, if that.

If that's the case I'd argue the tuning is wrong, not the mechanic.  The intent of the AD ratio is to ensure that he does not do sufficient damage while building full tank.  

Vi's W has a similar split that seems to work pretty well.  She needs to build some AD and AS to get her W proc to really shine.

>Vi's W has a similar split that seems to work pretty well. She needs to build some AD and AS to get her W proc to really shine.

Pure tank Vi builds tend to work at least as well as bruiser builds and have generally been the most viable build path for her historically.

Not speaking to Kled here, but as an overall comment on "% health damage on fighters."

In the past I have tended to use % health damage as less of a "I kill tanks" stat and more of "I don't one-shot sqiushies" stat.

That probably sounds weird, but hear me out here:
Say your champion, Talon, is only good at killing Ashe and nothing else.  That guy better be **really good** at killing Ashe, else he's going to be useless. Given how safe Ashe tends to be (especially when she has a Janna on her team) it's likely Talon is going to need some mechanics that result in him one-shotting her before she can respond. 

Talon is viable, but Ashe has a bad time.

Now imagine that Talon had mechanics in his kit that allowed him to have some degree of success vs. champions who aren't Ashe.  In this case Talon can be **less good** at killing Ashe because he can contribute to the team in other ways.  Wooo, Joe's success case is now less binary and Ashe doesn't get one-shot as much.

% health damage is one such mechanic.  It can allow a character who might normally be very focused on murdering squishies to have success cases against tanks, which means we can make their overall effectiveness against said squishies lower and possibly less frustrating.

Of course there's tradeoffs here.  % health damage isn't always a good idea or the right thing to do, given the champion we're putting it on.  Gains in one area often come with costs in another.  Tank Ekko and Fizz showed us the dark side of more target agnostic assassins for example.

------------------------------
Side note: Tanks  can still respond to % health damage by buliding Armor/MR.  That means a tank doing well is still going to outpace a %health char doing poorly (assuming the right tuning).  This is why %health true damage has always been so contentious.

You're not wrong.... 

Using it certainly has brought health to the adcs life because getting one shot by assassins is a big deal, and this is one way of dealing with it. I would argue that the unhealthy side effect is that it makes tanks less relevant. Hear me out. Tanks can respond to %HP damage with resistances in most cases, but it still means that they can't survive against such target agnostic enemies (because you've traded off ADC quality of life in exchange for the tanks who can now be viably focused). Given that tanks can't really tank as much you need to give them something to be relevant and many have been given damage. Some through their kits in giving them %HP damage of their own, some through itemization like DMP, some through keystone masteries, etc.... Now tanks are doing more damage without being able to effectively tank while adcs are taking less damage without doing less damage while neither need to build damage or defenses respectively to do so. 

To a lot of people this looks dangerously like damage creep and/or champion homogenization. 

It also feels pretty bad to die so quickly when you're building nothing but tank items. That too. 

I would argue that a better solution would be to give tanks the tools necessary to protect their adcs.

Unfortunately, that's barely true.  If someone gains 10% effective health against physical damage, they can do it either by gaining health or armour:
2000 hp -> 2200 hp
OR
100 armour -> 120 armour

So we can do the math on 20% max hp damage:
In the 2000 hp, 120 armour case, it's 400 damage, reduced to 400*(100/220)=182, or 9.1% of the target's max health.
In the 2200 hp, 100 armour case, it's 440 damage, reduced to 440*(100/200)=220, or 10% of the target's max health.

So for a given amount of effective physical health, each point of armour increases effective health by 0.5% against physical percent health damage.  What this means is that armour, while effective, gives less of a bonus than building health against normal damage.  It does reduce the actual damage by 1%, but the percent damage by less.
